text: hey everyone thomas joseph here now do
your burgers turn out like this where
they look like they're done on the
outside but when you break into them
they're overcooked dry and kind of
crumbly like this one here well today
I'm going to share with you a few tips
and tricks in burger success the real
important thing here is to get really
great quality meat now I have one and a
half pounds of ground beef here and this
is actually ground chuck which is from
the shoulder region of the cow and that
has a lot of really great flavor
you want to make sure that you get 80/20
and what 80/20 means is 80% meat and 20%
fat try to avoid the leaner ground beef
that says 90/10 because you really need
the fat otherwise you're going to end up
with a dry burger for burgers I prefer
them to be a little bit bigger in size
so I'm going to create from this one and
a half pounds four six ounce patties so
there we go that's about six ounces
there now to form your burger patties
what I like to do I do this with
meatballs is I like to throw the meat in
between my hands handling it less and
not melting the fat in the meat so what
this does is it compacts the meat
together compacts the burger so that
doesn't fall apart on the grill and it's
a lot less contact and you're not
warming up the meat so that looks pretty
good I'm going to flatten this out into
a 4-inch patty when you're forming the
patty create a divot in the center of
the burger because what happens the meat
retracts and if you don't create this
divot in the center it's going to create
a dome shape or more of a meatball shape
on your grill so make sure that you
create this divot in the center now for
seasoning I'm using salt and pepper very
simple but whenever you're seasoning
your burgers ground meat don't season
too far in advance because what that
does the salt it pulls out the moisture
and you really don't want to do that you
want to have a nice moist burger and use
a generous amount of salt and pepper
because this is really the only
flavoring for the burger flip the
burgers on the other side and season
but I have a grill heating this is over
a medium-high heat so this is direct
heat and if you're doing this outside on
your gas grill or using charcoal you
really do want a hot hot grill to sear
the burgers so I have a little bit of
safflower oil any neutral oil here and a
paper towel and make sure that you boil
the grates of your grill because you
really don't want the burger to stick
now if you're doing this outside make
sure you use a pair of tongs
to help you out with this place your
burgers flat side down on the grill to
cook the burgers you really want to cook
them on this one side for about three
minutes and three minutes is good for a
6-ounce burger if you're doing an
8-ounce burger which is a half a pound
you might have to extend the cooking
process a little bit so that might take
anywhere between four or five minutes
per side but for a nice medium-rare
burger three minutes per side is really
what you're looking for so it's been
three minutes and you can see the
burgers are starting to shrink up a
little bit and that's great because we
want them to be a little bit smaller we
don't want them to overpower the bun but
we certainly don't want them to shrink
up into tiny little burgers and now I'm
going to flip the burger and I think
it's really important whenever you're
making burgers that you just flip them
once you don't press them pressing them
what it does is gonna push out any
moisture in the burger and now you want
to continue to cook the burgers for
another three to four minutes now I'm
making cheese burgers today and that's
when you want to add your cheese when
you flip them so this is some nice
thinly sliced cheddar one slice per
burger you could do two if you really
wanted to and now what I like to do is
cover with a lid and the cheese will
melt and the burger will continue to
cook nice and evenly so it's been
another three minutes the cheese is nice
and melted here remove your burgers to a
platter or a rimmed baking sheet just
let them rest for a little bit you don't
want to serve them right off the grill
and this will give me a little bit of
time to toast the bun it's really
important you guys go the extra mile and
toast the bun
it makes the burger that much better so
just 30 seconds
to toast that and of course have ready
all of the toppings that you like 30
seconds the bun is nicely toasted and
now to stack the burger I always like to
place the patty on the bottom of the bun
a slice or two of tomato two leaves of
lettuce and of course mayonnaise a nice
good amount of mayo on the top of the
bun so with a burger this big you might
need to secure it with one of these
wooden skewers but there you go guys
the tricks and tips behind ultimate
burger success enjoy these all summer
long and as always if you have any
kitchen conundrums write in the comments
section below or reach out to me using
the hashtag kitchen conundrums and I
will solve whatever problems you thrown
my way enjoy guys
you
